title-group.article-title: Association of miR-146aC>G, miR-196a2T>C, and miR-499A>G Polymorphisms With Risk of Premature Ovarian Failure in Korean Women

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Biomedical Science, College of Life Science, CHA University, Seongnam, South Korea
2Institute for Clinical Research, CHA Bundang Medical Center, CHA University, Seongnam, South Korea
3Fertility Center of CHA Gangnam Medical Center, CHA University, Seoul, South Korea
4Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, CHA Bundang Medical Center, CHA University, Seongnam, South Korea

author-notes.corresp: Nam Keun Kim, Institute for Clinical Research, CHA Bundang Medical Center, CHA University, 351 Yatap-dong, Bundang-gu, Seongnam 463-712, South Korea Email: nkkim@cha.ac.kr

abstract.p: We investigated whether microRNA (miRNA) polymorphisms (miR-146aC>G, miR-196a2T>C, and miR-499A>G) confer risk of premature ovarian failure (POF) in Korean women. DNA samples from 136 patients with POF and 234 controls were genotyped for the 3 miRNA single-nucleotide polymorphisms by polymerase chain reaction–restriction fragment length polymorphism. The miR-146aCG/miR-196a2TC combined genotype was less frequent in patients than in controls (P < .05), conferring less susceptibility. Using haplotype-based multifactor dimensionality reduction analysis, the C-C-A and G-T-A inferred haplotypes (miR-146a/miR-196a2/miR-499) were less frequent in patients, suggesting protective effects (P < .05 for each), whereas the C-T-A and G-C-A haplotypes were more frequent in patients (P < .05 for each). The C-T and G-C haplotypes (miR-146a/miR-196a2) were more frequent in patients, whereas the C-C and G-T haplotypes were less frequent in patients (P < .05 for each). However, none of the 3 miRNA polymorphisms alone was associated with POF risk. Our findings suggest that putative gene–gene interaction between miR-146 and miR-196a2 may be involved in POF development.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are a family of short (~22 nucleotides), noncoding, endogenous RNA molecules that regulate gene expression at the posttranscriptional level by destabilizing or cleaving target messenger RNAs (mRNAs). Approximately one third of human genes have been reported to be conserved miRNA targets, indicating that miRNAs are key regulators of various biological pathways.1 Biosynthesis of miRNAs takes several steps: initially, RNA polymerase II produces a 500 to 3000 nucleotide transcript—called the primary miRNA—that is processed to form a precursor miRNA (pre-miRNA at ~60-100 nucleotides) hairpin by a multiprotein complex that includes DROSHA. After pre-miRNA is exported to the cytoplasm by RAN and XPO5, and additionally processed by DICER1, which is a polymerase II enzyme responsible for miRNA processing, a double-stranded miRNA duplex is generated that unwinds and forms a single-stranded, mature miRNA (~22 nucleotides).2–5 The mature miRNAs incorporate into the RNA-induced silencing complex and through complementary binding with target gene mRNA result in sequence-specific translational repression or mRNA degradation.6 Through this mechanism, miRNAs are considered to influence the outcome of various cellular activities under normal and disease states.7 Moreover, the association between miRNA polymorphisms and recurrent spontaneous abortion (RSA) has been reported later.8

Timely coordinated regulation of the expression of numerous genes are critical for optimal expression of gonadotropins, intraovarian mediators, and their receptors that mediate their intracellular actions during folliculogenesis and ovulation,9–10 and alteration in the expression of these genes could lead to abnormal follicle recruitment and development.7 Since the importance of miRNAs in folliculogenesis has been illustrated by unveiling that disruption of DICER1 results in failed meiotic maturation by oocytes,11–12 more studies have supported the regulatory function of miRNAs in the ovary, including inhibition of antral follicle development, induction of granulosa cell apoptosis, and reduced ovulatory efficiency.13–15 Recent studies have indicated the involvement of miRNAs in ovarian pathophysiology such as being involved in polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) and premature ovarian failure (primary ovarian failure [POF]).7,16 The PCOS, the most common cause of anovulatory infertility that affects approximately 8% of reproductive-age women,17 is characterized by arrested follicle development at the antral stage; additionally, altered expression or inappropriate signaling mechanisms of various intraovarian factors accounts for pathogenesis of PCOS.18–20 Aberrant expression of the miR-29 family and its specific target genes involved in folliculogenesis could result in ovarian dysfunction such as PCOS.7,21 The POF affects approximately 1% of women aged less than 40 years and refers to the development of amenorrhea with elevated serum follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels (> 40 IU/L) due to cessation of ovarian function.22–25 More than 90% of POF cases have unknown causes.25–26 A recent study identified that knockout mice without miR-290 through miR-295 are sterile due to POF.16 miR-146a is one of the miRNAs enriched in the oocyte with dramatic changes in expression levels depending on different maturation times during bovine oocyte maturation and preimplantation embryo development.27 Targets of miR-146a include the FAS gene,28,29 and FAS induces oocyte apoptosis during folliculogenesis.30 miR-196a is expressed during oocyte maturation and bovine early embryonic development and regulates the expression of the newborn ovary homeobox (NOBOX) gene during bovine early embryogenesis.31 Mutations in the NOBOX gene have been reported to cause POF.32 Very recently, we reported an interesting finding of the association between RSA risk and polymorphisms of miR-196a2 and miR-499.8 miR-499, abundantly and specifically expressed only in the heart, could not be detected in other tissues in a swine model.33 However, miR-499 expression was detected in an invasive breast cancer cell line,34 and a miR-499 single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) was associated with increased risk of breast cancer in Chinese women.35 Mutations of the BRCA1 gene responsible for breast cancer have been reported to be associated with occult POF and suggested a potential link between breast cancer and female infertility.36 We hypothesized that miRNA polymorphisms may be associated with infertility by conferring POF risk. The purpose of the present study was to investigate the association of miR-146aC>G (rs2910164), miR-196a2T>C (rs11614913), and miR-499A>G (rs3746444) with POF risk.

sec.title: Study Participants
sec.p: The study group consisted of 136 women (age range, 21-43 years; mean age ± standard deviation [SD], 31.34 ± 4.97 years) who were diagnosed with POF (cessation of menstruation before 40 years of age and 2 serum FSH concentration measurements >40 IU/L) at the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology of CHA Bundang Medical Center from March 1999 to February 2008. Patients with a history of pelvic surgery, cancer, radiation exposure, autoimmune disorder, or genetic syndromes were excluded from the present study. The control group consisted of 234 women (age range, 23-43 years; mean age ± SD, 32.54 ± 3.88 years) who had regular menstrual cycles and at least 1 live birth. The control group was recruited from CHA Bundang Medical Center. All patients and controls were Korean. The institutional review board of CHA Bundang Medical Center approved the study in 2006, and informed consent was obtained from all participants.

sec.title: Hormone Assays
sec.p: For measurement of FSH, luteinizing hormone (LH), and estradiol (E2) levels, blood samples were collected by venipuncture on the second or third menstrual cycle day. These hormones were measured by either radioimmunoassay (E2; Beckman Coulter, Inc, Fullerton, CA) or enzyme immunoassay (FSH and LH; Siemens, Los Angeles, CA) following the manufacturer’s instructions after the serum was separated as described previously.37

sec.title: Genetic Analysis of miRNA Sequence Polymorphisms
sec.p: Genomic DNA was extracted from anticoagulated peripheral blood using a G-DEX blood extraction kit (iNtRON Biotechnology, Seongnam, South Korea). The nucleotide changes were determined by polymerase chain reaction–restriction fragment length polymorphism (PCR-RFLP) analysis as previously described.38 Primer sequences for PCR amplification of each polymorphism were as follows: miR-146aC>G: forward 5′-CAT GGG TTG TGT CAG TGT CAG AGC T-3′ and reverse 5′-TGC CTT CTG TCT CCA GTC TTC CAA-3′ (mismatch sequence is underlined); miR-196a2T>C: forward 5′-CCC CTT CCC TTC TCC TCC AGA TA-3′ and reverse 5′-CGA AAA CCG ACT GAT GTA ACT CCG-3′; and miR-499A>G: forward 5′-CAA AGT CTT CAC TTC CCT GCC A-3′ and reverse 5′-GAT GTT TAA CTC CTC TCC ACG TGA TC-3′. We performed restriction enzyme digestion with SacI and MspI (New England BioLabs, Ipswich, Massachusetts) for the miR-146aC>G and 196a2T>C polymorphisms, respectively, at 37°C for 16 hours, and Bcl I digestion for the 499A>G polymorphism at 50°C for 16 hours. We confirmed the genotyping of the 3 sites by sequencing 10% of the samples.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: We calculated the statistical power and sample size of our study using QUANTO software version 1.2 (available at http://hydra.usc.edu/gxe/).39,40 The desired power of the study was set at 80%, a 2-tailed P value <.05 was deemed to indicate statistical significance, and we used the parameters (eg, minor allele frequencies) our group previously found.8 We compared the differences in hormone levels between the 2 groups using t test.

Differences in the genotype frequencies between controls and POF patients were compared using chi-square test or Fisher exact test. Allele frequencies were calculated to investigate deviations from Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium (HWE). Odds ratios (ORs) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) were used to measure the strength of the association between genotypes and POF. We analyzed gene–gene interaction among the 3 miRNA loci using the multifactor-dimensionality reduction (MDR) method and MDR software version 2.0 (www.epistasis.org).41–43 Using MDR method, we constructed all possible combinations of the 3 polymorphisms. We estimated inferred haplotype frequencies from haplotype-based MDR analysis using SNPAlyze version 5.1 (Dynacom Co, Ltd, Yokohama, Japan) for the polymorphisms determined to have strong synergistic effects by MDR analysis. The false discovery rate (FDR) correction was used to adjust multiple comparison tests and associations with FDR <.05 were deemed to indicate statistical significance.44 Statistical analyses were performed using GraphPad Prism 4.0 (GraphPad Software Inc, San Diego, California) and StatsDirect software version 2.4.4 (StatsDirect Ltd, Altrincham, UK). Significant associations between inferred haplotypes and POF were assessed by permuting case and control status and recalculating the test statistic 1000 times for each of the sample sets. Statistical significance was accepted at P < .05.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Power calculation indicated that our study was powered to detect an association between a gene and disease, assuming an OR of 2.000 to 2.500 ( Supplement Table 1 for a single gene), and an association between interaction of 2 genes and disease, assuming an OR of 4.000 ( Supplement Table 2 for gene–gene interaction) with a power >80%.

caption.p: Demographic and Clinical Characteristics of Korean POF Patients and Controls

fn.p: Abbreviations: SD, standard deviation; NS, not significant; FSH, follicle-stimulating hormone; LH, luteinizing hormone; POF, premature ovarian failure.
a P value by t test.

caption.p: Genotype Frequencies of miR-146aC>G, miR-196a2T>C, and miR-499A>G Polymorphisms in Korean POF Patients and Controls

fn.p: Abbreviations: POF, premature ovarian failure; OR, odds ratio; CI, confidence interval; HWE p, Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium P Value.
a P Value by Fisher exact test; otherwise P value by chi-square test.

sec.p: Demographic and clinical characteristics, including FSH, LH, and E2 levels of POF patients and controls, are summarized for comparison in Table 1. The 2 groups were matched in terms of age. The patients with POF showed significantly increased FSH and LH levels and decreased E2 levels compared with control women. Elevation of FSH levels with a value >40 mIU/mL and less marked elevation of LH levels are indicative of POF.

The genotype and allele frequencies of miR-146a, miR-196a2, and miR-499 polymorphisms were compared between controls and patients with POF (Table 2). All genotype distributions in the study patients were in HWE. However, none of the 3 miRNA polymorphisms was alone associated with POF risk.

In combination analysis of the genotypes of the 3 polymorphisms (Table 3), the CC/CC, CG/TT, CG/TC, and GG/TT combined genotypes for the miR-146a/miR-196a2 loci were significantly less frequent in patients with POF than in controls compared with the CC/TT genotype as the reference (OR = 0.304, 95% CI = 0.107-0.869; OR = 0.422, 95% CI = 0.184-0.972; OR = 0.411, 95% CI = 0.200-0.847; OR = 0.193, 95% CI = 0.037-1.002, respectively), suggesting that these genotypes are associated with protective effects on POF. Among these combined genotypes, the CG/TC genotype remained significant after multiple comparison correction using FDR (FDR = 0.045). For the miR-146a/miR-499 loci, the CG/AA combined genotype was significantly less frequent in patients with POF than in controls compared with the CC/AA genotype as the reference (OR = 0.566, 95% CI = 0.326-0.981); however, the association with POF was not significant after FDR correction (FDR = 0.063). We observed no significant association between miR-196a2/miR-499 and POF occurrence.

caption.p: Combination Analysis of miR-146aC>G, miR-196a2T>C, and miR-499A>G Polymorphisms in Korean POF Patients and Controls

fn.p: Abbreviations: POF, premature ovarian failure; OR, odds ratio; CI, confidence interval; FDR, false discovery rate; N/A, not available.
a P Value by Fisher exact test; otherwise P value by chi-square test.

sec.p: Haplotype-based analyses of the 3 miRNA polymorphisms using the MDR method are presented in Table 4. Among the inferred haplotypes for the 3 miRNAs, the C-C-A and G-T-A haplotypes were less frequent in patients with POF than in controls and conferred less POF susceptibility (OR = 0.581, 95% CI = 0.397-0.852; OR = 0.433, 95% CI = 0.274-0.683, respectively), whereas the C-T-A and G-C-A haplotypes were more frequent in patients with POF than in controls suggesting more POF susceptibility (OR = 1.717, 95% CI = 1.242-2.373; OR = 1.491, 95% CI = 1.016-2.188, respectively). In analyses of miR-146a/miR-196a2, the C-T and G-C haplotypes were more frequent in patients with POF (OR = 1.583, 95% CI = 1.159-2.162; OR = 1.822, 95% CI = 1.251-2.653, respectively), suggesting association with an increased risk of POF, whereas the C-C and G-T haplotypes were less frequent in patients with POF (OR = 0.601, 95% CI = 0.422-0.857; OR = 0.514, 95% CI = 0.345-0.766, respectively), suggesting a protective nature. Permutation tests confirmed the significance of the associations (P < .05). For the miR-146a/miR-499, the G-G haplotype frequency was higher in patients with POF (OR = 1.984, 95% CI = 1.030-3.821); however, its significance was not continued after the permutation test (P = .062).

caption.p: Haplotype-based Analysis of miR-146aC>G, miR-196a2T>C, and miR-499A>G Polymorphisms in Korean POF Patients and Controls Using the MDR Method

fn.p: Abbreviations: POF, premature ovarian failure; OR, odds ratio; CI, confidence interval; N/A, not available; MDR, multifactor-dimensionality reduction.
a P value by chi-square test.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Increasing evidence has supported the roles of miRNAs in spermatogenesis and male infertility.45–49 Simultaneously, evidence supporting the role of miRNAs in oocyte maturation and ovarian function has also been accumulating,7,11–16,27 leading us to investigate whether 3 pre-miRNA SNPs (miR-146aC>G, miR-196a2T>C, and miR-499A>G), which have been shown to associate with various types of cancer and RSA, confer risk of POF in Korean women.8,35,50–54 To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report to evaluate the association between miRNA polymorphisms and POF risk. Our findings suggest that the miR-146a CG/miR-196a2 TC combined genotype is associated with POF risk (a protective nature) relative to the CC/TT combined genotype, and its significant association was upheld after multiple comparison correction using FDR. Although none of the 3 miRNA polymorphism alone was associated with POF risk, the combined genotype of miR-146aC>T and miR-196a2T>C polymorphisms was associated with POF risk, suggesting potential gene–gene interaction between the 2 miRNA polymorphisms. Because gene–gene interaction may affect gene–disease association55–56 and the MDR method is known to detect gene–gene interaction regardless of their chromosomal locations,41–43 we took a novel approach to examine potential interactive effects of different miRNAs on POF risk using haplotype-based MDR analysis, although linkage disequilibrium was not found among the miRNAs. Previously, we took this approach to evaluate synergistic effects of the pre-miRNA polymorphisms on idiopathic RSA risk.8 The haplotype-based MDR analysis of the 3 miRNA polymorphisms also suggested gene–gene interaction between miR-146aC>G and miR-196a2T>C polymorphisms (miR-146aC/miR-19a2C and miR-146aG/miR-196a2T inferred haplotypes as a protective factor; miR-146aC/miR-196a2T and miR-146aG/miR-196a2C inferred haplotypes as a risk factor). More combined genotypes (CC/CC, CG/TT, and GG/TT combined genotypes of miR-146a C>G/miR-196a2 T>C loci; the CG/AA combined genotype of miR-146a C>G/miR-499 A>G loci) also have protective effects against POF occurrence; however, its significance did not last after FDR correction.

Among the 3 miRNAs investigated in our study, miR-146a is expressed in the oocyte during bovine oocyte maturation and preimplantation embryo development and has a putative target site in the 3′-untranslated region (UTR) of FAS mRNA to regulate FAS expression.27–28 The FAS gene is expressed in both unfertilized oocytes and cumulus cells and coordinate oocyte apoptosis during folliculogenesis by binding with FAS ligand on oocytes, which may result in caspase 8 activation.29,30 miR-146a, which is NF-κB dependent for its induction, is also involved in regulation of the tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-α pathway by targeting TNF receptor-associated factor 6.57,58 The TNF-α, expressed in granulosa cells, is involved in follicular development and atresia by activating a cascade of caspases like FAS-FAS ligand.59–61 miR-196a, detected significantly in fetal and adult ovary, binds to the 3′-UTR of bovine NOBOX mRNA and significantly inhibits NOBOX expression in vitro.31 The NOBOX gene, preferentially expressed in primordial and growing oocytes, is a regulator of the development of primordial to primary follicles and is associated with POF.32,62,63 miR-499 is expressed specifically in the heart, and direct evidence for involvement of miR-499 in ovarian function has yet to be reported. However, targets of miR-499 include the transcriptional repressor SOX6 gene that represses transcription from the fibroblast growth factor (FGF)-3 promoter.33,64,65 The FGF-3 is known to play a role in cell proliferation and differentiation in embryonic tissues66 and is associated with the risk of breast and ovarian cancers.67,68 Interestingly, miR-499 expression was detected in an invasive breast cancer cell line,33,34 and the miR-499A>G polymorphism was associated with an increased risk of breast cancer in Chinese women.35 BRCA1 mutation-positive breast patients have been reported to demonstrate a significantly higher risk of low response to ovarian stimulation (lower numbers of eggs), suggesting a potential link between breast cancer and female infertility.36 We also found that miR-499A>G polymorphism as well as miR-196a2T>C polymorphism is associated with idiopathic RSA in Korean women.8 However, we found no significant association between the miR-499A>G polymorphism and POF risk in our study.

It is anticipated that miRNAs may work in combination because the interactions among the miRNAs have been suggested as necessary for more precise specification of the set of affected targets of each miRNA.69 One way to estimate the interactions of miRNAs is to identify pairs of miRNAs that show a high rate of co-occurrence in the same target mRNAs, such as predicted pairs of co-regulating miRNAs.69 Our findings showed that the miR-146aC allele in relation to the miR-196a2T allele increased POF risk, whereas miR-146aC in relation to miR-196a2C decreased POF risk, suggesting the interaction between miR-146a and miR-196a2 polymorphisms is associated with the risk of POF. Our speculation for the interactive effects of polymorphisms of the 2 miRNAs on POF risk, however, requires evidence from in vitro functional data in further studies to provide a similar proof of principle to evaluate synergistic effects among the miRNAs tested.70

Polymorphisms in pre-miRNAs can affect the levels of mature miRNAs as miR-146aG and miR-196a2T alleles decrease corresponding mature miRNA levels.50,53,71,72 Upregulated miR-196a2 has been reported to affect mRNA expression of the HOX family and AKT signaling, which is linked to endometriosis.73–75 Spatiotemporal aberrations in HOX gene expression are implicated in endometriosis as well as PCOS.73 We conjectured that sequence polymorphisms of miR-146a and miR-196a2 may affect folliculogenesis by altering miRNA biogenesis and subsequently target genes of the miRNAs. Due to limited access to ovary samples from patients with POF, however, we could not compare expression levels of miRNAs and target genes according to the miRNA genotypes, which may be a major challenge for our study. Although underlying mechanisms of the miR-146a and miR-196a2 polymorphisms in the development of POF have not been demonstrated in our study, previous studies on the miRNAs and their target genes led us to postulate their potential role in oocyte apoptosis during folliculogenesis. Another weakness of our study is that a replication study to verify our findings is warranted. Our study is also limited by the number of cases and controls. As the power calculation indicated, our sample size was large enough to detect an association between POF and miR-499 polymorphisms, although the association was not significant. However, our study did not have sufficient power to detect the association between POF and individual miR-146a or miR-196a2 polymorphisms. For the gene–gene interaction model, our study with samples was sufficient to detect the association between POF, and the interaction of miR-196a2 and miR-499 failed to detect a significant association. However, the present study detected an association between POF and interaction of miR-146a and miR-196a2 when the estimated power was <80%. A lack of association between POF and individual miR-146a or miR-196a2 polymorphisms, but significant association between POF and the interaction of miR-146a and miR-196a2, may indicate that a larger number of samples is needed to present a single gene effect on POF risk.

In conclusion, we have identified that combined polymorphisms and inferred haplotypes of miR-146aC>G, miR-196a2T>C, and miR-499A>G are associated with the occurrence of POF in Korean women. Our data demonstrated that the miR-146aC allele in combination with the miR-196a2C allele as well as the miR-146aG allele in combination with the miR-196a2T allele reduced POF risk. However, the miR-146aC allele in combination with the miR-196a2T allele as well as the miR-146aG allele in combination with the miR-196a2C allele increased POF risk. Considering that none of the 3 miRNAs alone is associated with POF risk, our findings suggest that the gene–gene interaction between miR-146 and miR-196a2 may be involved in POF development. We postulated that transcriptional aberration of miR-146a and miR-196a2 induced by miRNA SNPs might influence target gene expression and subsequently, oocyte apoptosis during folliculogenesis, although the underlying mechanism remains to be elucidated in further studies.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
